How to Make Sure Your Couchsurfing Experience is 100% Safe

Tips on making your Couchsurfing experience as safe as possible.

As a solo female backpacker, I spend a lot of time thinking about how to Couchsurf safely. Thus far, as of July 2017, Iâ€™ve safely Couchsurfed 31 times, hosting guests 10 times and surfing 21 times.

The first thing Iâ€™ll point out is that there is no such thing as a 100% safe Couchsurfing experience. Iâ€™d argue thereâ€™s no such thing as a 100% safe travel experience, either. These things can always carry a small inherent danger that prevents someone from guaranteeing 100% safety. But you can get pretty darn close with the tips below.

1. Only stay with people with a large number of reviews.

Additionally, donâ€™t interact, stay with, or host people who have 0 references or seem off in some way.

Every person on the platform has a reference section which details what staying with them is like. Itâ€™s just like a Yelp or Airbnb review. As a solo surfer, stay away from people who donâ€™t have reviews â€“ while theyâ€™re likely great people, they could also be more sinister, and since you cannot differentiate which of the two they are, donâ€™t stay with them or meet up in person.

How many is â€˜largeâ€™? This depends on how trusting you are of the community. Iâ€™d say the following is a good outline:

  • Very Relaxed Safety Standards: 10-15 reviews
  • Average Safety Standards: : 15-30 reviews
  • Strict Safety Standards: : 30+ reviews

When I surf, I generally will stay with people with 12+ reviews â€“ if theyâ€™re in the 12-22 range of reviews, Iâ€™ll be sure to analyze the references and make sure theyâ€™re above-and-beyond.

Generally, speaking, if they have 30+ positive reviews, theyâ€™re very, very likely to be fantastic hosts. It still helps to take some of the precautions listed below, especially if youâ€™re new to Couchsurfing.

Also, if someone seems â€˜offâ€™ when messaging you, err on the side of caution and find another host. One of my to-be hosts with about ~7 reviews once messaged me with a â€˜Hi ;)â€™; of course, it could have been well-meaning but I didnâ€™t want to take the chance â€“ I quickly arranged another option and didnâ€™t stay with the host.

I personally surf with both men and women but if youâ€™re a beginner female Couchsurfer who is very uneasy about the idea of staying with a male host, you can always choose to stay with only female hosts, but note that your choices in hosts will be very limited. That being said, itâ€™s still a good way to dip oneâ€™s toe into the community to see what itâ€™s like if you can find a host.

If Iâ€™m still not sure if itâ€™s safe, Iâ€™ll do some of the things outlined below.

2.If someone offers to host you (instead of responding to your request) be extra sure they have a large number of great reviews.

If I do accept to stay with hosts who offer to host me, itâ€™s only because they have a large number of positive reviews. If they offer to host me, usually Iâ€™d need 15-40+ reviews to feel comfortable staying with them.

3. Contact people who have stayed with the host before

Again, to double check the safety of a host, especially if youâ€™re very uneasy about surfing with a male host, you can message women or past surfers who have stayed at the potential hostâ€™s place and ask them if they felt safe and what the host is like.

To do this:

  • Navigate to the hostâ€™s â€˜Referencesâ€™ page and click on the profiles of those who have stayed with him/her before.
  • Send them a message asking about their experience with the host and if they felt safe. Make sure to do this with 5-7 hosts if possible (or as many as you can in case some donâ€™t respond).

This has been incredibly helpful for me in the past, with screenshots of what Iâ€™ve sent as an example below. If any one of them report anything â€˜offâ€™, donâ€™t take the risk and find another host.

4. Analyze the references carefully

Good hosts usually have a large number of rave reviews referring to the host as super great and generous. If a number of reviews have more neutral tones or mention things that seem â€˜offâ€™, itâ€™s better to dig deeper by contacting previous surfers.

In Conclusion: Is it safe?

If you follow the guidelines above, yes.

Of my 31 Couchsurfing experiences, all have been positive ones. The closest Iâ€™ve come to in terms of trouble were 2 guys who subtly hit on me; when I made a point of declining, they totally honored it and both experiences were entirely positive.

My good experiences on Couchsurfing.com have been purely because of the precautions I took above; a number of travelers who donâ€™t take these precautions naturally will have bad experiences.

In other words, if you follow the guidelines above, I have a hard time believing youâ€™ll have a bad experience traveling â€“ especially if you stay with hosts with only 30-40+ reviews and reach out to 5 or so of their past surfers. The Couchsurfing community offers so much richness when traveling. My best experiences abroad have almost always involved my hosts and surfers.

And thatâ€™s pretty much it! Take the steps above, embrace your freedom and Couchsurf on!
